metadata.title: Subtractive manufacturing of stable hierarchical micro-nano structures on AA5052 sheet with enhanced water repellence and durable corrosion resistance

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials and Design
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/matdes
Subtractive manufacturing of stable hierarchical micro-nano structures on AA5052 sheet with enhanced water repellence and durable corrosion resistance
Xuewu Li a, 1, Tian Shi a, 1, Ben Li b, *, Xinchun Chen c, *, Chuanwei Zhang a, Zhiguang Guo d, *, Qiaoxin Zhang b
a School of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an University of Science and Technology, Xi'an 710054, China b School of Mechanical and Electronic Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, 122 Luoshi Road, Wuhan 430070, China c State Key Laboratory of Tribology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China d State Key Laboratory of Solid Lubrication, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China
h i g h l i g h t s
* Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: lixuewu55@xust.edu.cn (X. Li), t
edu.cn (C. Zhang), zguo@licp.cas.cn (Z. Guo). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matdes.2019.108152 0264-1275/© 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
One-step electron discharge machining of stable hierarchical micro-nano structures is achieved. The machined surface shows enhanced water-repellent, selfcleaning and anti-adhesion behaviors. The surface acts as a durable barrier against seawater corrosion and bacteria adhesion. Anti-corrosion mechanisms of various wetting states are systematically investigated.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 April 2019 Received in revised form 11 July 2019 Accepted 22 August 2019 Available online 23 August 2019
Keywords: Subtractive manufacturing Structural stability Water repellence Corrosion resistance Bacteria inhibition
Data availability: Representative researchdata sets aregiven in figures.Other raw/processeddata required to reproduce these findings cannot be shared at
a b s t r a c t
Preparing super-hydrophobic surfaces with additive manufacturing (AM) and multi-step processes improves corrosion resistance of Al alloys. But the incorporation of dissimilar metals accelerates matrix corrosion, additive polymers cannot offer a long-term structural stability, and multi-step methods are complicated and costly. Hereon, stable micro-craters and nano-terraces on AA5052 sheet with enhanced water repellence and durable corrosion resistance are fabricated via low-cost subtractive manufacturing (SM) strategy. After fluoridation process, as-fabricated hierarchical structures possess highlighted selfcleaning and anti-adhesion capabilities. The following electrochemical test shows that the resultant surface effectively acts as a barrier against seawater infiltration suggesting superior anti-corrosion capacity. Meanwhile, the bacterial colony count test shows that the surface also possesses excellent resistance to microbiological adhesion. Such economic, efficient and environmental SM process is of great potential in fabricating multifunctional Al alloys with durable anti-corrosion, super-hydrophobic and bacteriostatic behaviors. © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND
license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).
ianshi@xust.edu.cn (T. Shi), liyiben@whut.edu.cn (B. Li), chenxc1213@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn (X. Chen), zhangcw@xust.
Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).
this time as the data also forms part of an ongoing study, but they can be obtained from corresponding authors on reasonable requests.
1. Introduction bioadhesion resistance. The research has realistic significances in
AA5052 have attracted extensive interests in engineering researches, daily lives and industrial productions [1,2]. Especially in oceanic fields, they have been used as engineering plates, structural parts and welding components [3,4]. Generally, oxidation layers naturally develop to resist substrate corrosion [5,6]. However, under marine environments, active anions easily erode protective layers leading to metallic failures [7]. Moreover, microbial adhesion is also a common problem causing material invalidations [8].
To improve corrosion resistance of Al alloys, arc spraying [9], oxidation process [10], ageing treatment [11], laser process [12], alloying technology [13] and some other protection strategies [14,15] have been reported. It is well-known that the resulting microstructural array has also an important role in bothmechanical and corrosion behavior of a number of Al-based alloys [16e20]. In this sense, the microstructural refinement level and cathode-toanode area ratio constituted will strongly affect the mechanicalto-corrosion response [16e20]. Nevertheless, laser process is costly and unmanageable. Coating treatments with heavy metal ions usually pollute environment. Ageing and oxidation technologies are complicated, and sophisticated equipment are necessary. Hence, simple, green and economic anti-corrosion strategies for Al alloys are highly anticipated.
Enlightened by lotus leaves [21e24], super-hydrophobic surfaces prevent interactions with aggressive chlorides leading to greatly depressed corrosion rates. Therefore, water-repellent preparations are new-fashioned and effective anti-corrosion strategies for Al alloys. Generally, a super-hydrophobic surface with a small sliding angle (SA< 10 ) and a big static contact angle (CA> 150 ) can be attained by fabricating micro-nano structures and low-surfaceenergy layers [25e28]. By now, many AM methods have been reported to prepare super-hydrophobic structures on Al alloys for resisting corrosions, such as deposition [29], grafting [30], sol-gel process [31], hydrothermal synthesis [32], spinning [33], spraying [34] and in suit polymerisation [35]. Besides, multi-step processes have also been developed to protect Al alloys from corrosions. Liu et al. [36], Wang et al. [37] and Wu et al. [38] have reported waterrepellent Al sheets with enhanced corrosion resistance via multistep etching, anodization and modification. Rezayi et al. [39] have fabricated a multifunctional Al surface with super-hydrophobicity andcorrosionresistancevia immersion,ultrasoundandmodification.
However, for AM methods, the incorporation of dissimilar metals (such as deposition and spraying) accelerates corrosion failures of Al alloys, and additive polymers (such as grafting, spinning, sol-gel and synthesis) cannot offer a long-term structural stability. Meanwhile, multi-step anti-corrosion processes are complicated and costly, which limit their practical applications. Further, anti-corrosion mechanisms of various wetting states (hydrophilic, hydrophobic and super-hydrophobic) have rarely been systematically investigated. Based on these, developing low-cost SM methods to achieve stable super-hydrophobic structures with durable anti-corrosion behaviors has great practical values.
Herein, a low-cost, facile and large-scale SM process of superhydrophobic AA5052 sheet is achieved by electron discharge machining (EDM) strategy. Anti-corrosion tests and mechanisms of as-fabricated surfaces with various wetting states in seawater are investigated through interfacial interactions. Structural stability and durability are also examined. Additionally, as a typical marine microorganism, sulfate reducing bacteria (SRB) is used to assess its
broadening engineering applications of AA5052 sheets as barriers against corrosions.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: AA5052 sheets (Table 1) were purchased from Gemei Metal Materials Co., Ltd., Wuhan, China. Molybdenum wires (OB-20P, 80 mmdiameter)wereobtained fromMitsubishiElectricAutomation (China) Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. 1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorodecyltrichlorosilane modifier (FAS), SRB and other analytical reagents were achieved from Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, Beijing, China.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation
sections.text: AA5052 sheet was firstly cut into uniform specimens (10mm 20mm 2mm) using a DK7732C EDM system. In such process, molybdenum wire electrode was set as cathode, Al alloy sheet as anode, power tube number as 4, pulse width as 12 ms, machining frequency as 40 Hz, and pulse interval as 150 ms. After ultrasonically cleaning and drying, modification was carried out by dipping as-fabricated surfaces in alcohol solution of 20mmol FAS modifier for 12 h. The machining process is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1. As seen, hierarchical micro-craters and nanoterraces can be achieved on AA5052 sheet via such low-cost electron discharge machining process.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text: Scanning electron microscope (SEM, Quanta 200 FEG MKII, America) was used to observe morphologies. X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Quantera II) analysiswas carried out by anMgKa X-ray source. Contact angle instrument (OCA20, Germany) was adopted for measuring CA and SA. Electrochemical workstation (CHI660D, China)wasused for testing corrosion resistance in3.5wt% sodium chloride solution. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded between 10mHz and 100 kHz at a sine-wave amplitude of 10mV under open circuit potential (OCP), and potentiodynamicpolarization testwas carriedout from 1800 to 200mV versus saturatedcalomel electrode (SCE)witha scan rateof1mV$s 1. Bio-adhesive test was performed by immersing UV-irradiated sterile samples into SRB culture solution under an incubation condition (25 C,>90% relative humidity) for 2 and 4 days. The culture solution was achieved by mixing 2mL SRB and 10mL Luria-Bertani solution. Afterdegassing treatment, the solutionwas steamed (30min), sealed and then stored at 25 C. SEM and Fluorescent Microscopy (FM, XSP63XD) were used to analyze bacterial colonies.

sections.heading: 3.1. SM process of super-hydrophobic hierarchical structures
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows micro topographies of AA5052 substrate and
machined surface. Visibly, a comparatively smooth substrate with slight grinding cracks is available (Fig. 2a). After EDMprocess, micro craters at a size range of 10e20 mm are observed (Fig. 2b). Magnifying SEM images are used for revealing nanostructures (Fig. 2cee). As shown, nano-scale terraces (Fig. 2e) take shape on micro craters leading to hierarchical features. The formation of such structures is a result of localized fusion and evaporation of Al alloy substrate imposed by electrical discharges, as shown in Fig. 2f. Weak phases and dislocation defects are susceptible to discharges than other sites in crystal Al alloys. Hence, defects first melt leaving terrace structures exposure to surface. Meanwhile, continuous discharges bring about constant surface fusion and evaporation. Consequently, craters gradually develop on substrate.
Fig. 3 exhibits wetting capabilities of substrate, M-substrate (modified substrate) and M-M-sample (modified machined sample). Clearly, Al alloy substrate is hydrophilic (Fig. 3a). After modification, M-substrate has achieved a hydrophobic CA of 107.5 (Fig. 3b). But for M-M-sample, a super-hydrophobic CA of 161.3 is
available (Fig. 3d). SA is also necessary for evaluating wetting behaviors [40]. As shown, no droplet slippage occurs even M-substrate tilts to 90 (Fig. 3c). But a small SA of 3.6 is achieved for MM-sample indicating superior water repellence (Fig. 3e). Hence, super-hydrophobic Al alloy surface is available by preparing hierarchical micro-nano structures. The impacts of solid-air-liquid interfaces on super-hydrophobic capability are also clarified in Cassie-Baxter Equation [41]:
cosCA ¼ f1 cosq f2 ðf1 þ f2 ¼ 1Þ (1)
where f1 indicates contact ratio between droplet and surface, f2 refers to contact ratio between droplet and air, and q represents intrinsic contact angle of 107.5 . This equation reveals that forM-Msample, themaximalCAof 161.3 signifies adroplet 92.5%contacting with air while 7.5% with prepared surface looking as if a spheriform droplet stands upright on Al alloy surface (Fig. 3f). Awater adhesion test (4 mL) is conducted to evaluate adhesion resistance of M-M-
hined surface. (f) Schematic diagram of EDM process.
sample (Fig. 3g). Throughout the test, water drop is adsorbed on a pinhead. As sample keeps rising, a squeezed drop is observed. Note that,whensample shifts down, they lose touchand thedrop remains contact with pinhead. Moreover, there are no droplet residues on sample. This test indicates that M-M-sample shows potential applications as barriers against water adhesion.
Fig. 4adisplays a droplet bounce test onM-M-sample. It is carried out by freely dripping the droplet. As seen, the droplet bounces back and forth on surface before rolling down. Meanwhile, there are no droplet residues on sample. The self-cleaning ability ofM-M-sample is also evaluated in Fig. 4b. Beforehand, fine dusts are uniformly dispersed on sample. With droplets dripping off, they freely roll down and sweep away dusts along traces. Contrastively, for Al alloy substrate, droplets onlywet dusts showing strong viscous behaviors (Fig. 4c). Both the tests indicate thatM-M-sample possesses possible applications as drag-free and self-cleaning materials.
The enhanced hydrophobicity is linked with organic chains in FAS modifier. Fig. 5 exhibits contrastive XPS results of machined surface and modified counterpart. Apparently, new peaks of Al 2p
Fig. 4. (a) Snapshots of a droplet impacting M-M-sample. Self
(74.2 eV), Si 2p (100.9 eV) and F 1s (690.3 eV) are observed after modification. The high-resolution C 1s spectra on modified surface are decomposed into eC-metals (279.8 eV), eCeSi (281.9 eV), eCeC (285.0 eV), eCeO (286.3 eV), eCH2eCF2 (288.7 eV), eCF2 (291.0 eV) and eCF3 (294.0 eV). Si 2p spectra are assigned to SieC bonds (99.7 eV) and SieO bonds (101.9 eV) in FAS molecules. The results indicate that FAS monolayers have been bonded to machined surface after modification process.
The self-assembled mechanism of FAS molecule on machined Al alloy surface is also investigated in Fig. 6. During the hydrolytic process, the construction of FAS monolayer starts from ethyl group decomposition. Meanwhile, such monomer is polymerized with hydroxyl on machined surface to assemble FAS molecule in rough structures. Generally, F element possesses electron absorption effect, thus giving CeF group an intense chemical inertia [42]. Furthermore, CH group is effective against OH bond. Hence, low surface energy is achieved for FAS monolayer, which helps to repel water as well as guarantee machined surface superior superhydrophobicity.
-cleaning behaviors of (b) M-M-sample and (c) substrate.

sections.heading: 3.2. Corrosion resistance of as-prepared surfaces
sections.text:
Fig. 7 depicts polarization curves for characterizing corrosion resistance on Al alloys. In general, a sample with low current density is provided with weak electron-transfer capability as well as advantageous anti-corrosion behavior [43]. After extrapolation fittings, corrosion current densities (icorr) for substrate, M-substrate andM-M-sample are 1.19, 0.70 and 0.31 mA/cm2, respectively. These data indicate that M-M-sample possesses the optimal anticorrosion behavior, followed by M-substrate and then substrate.
After comparisons of icorr, substrate suffers serious erosion. It is a result of chlorine ions eroding metal substrate and causing severely corrosion failures (Fig. 8a). But for M-substrate, anti-corrosion behavior is greatly improved. This is ascribed to the FAS layer against seawater infiltration by preventing interface interactions with chlorides (Fig. 8b). Especially, the machined hierarchical surface plays a key role in trapping air, which serves as a parallel plate capacitor and obstructs interfacial charge transfers (Fig. 8c). Combining with impeditive effect of modified layer, M-M-sample achieves the optimal anti-corrosion behavior.
EIS curves with Nyquist plots (Fig. 9aec) and Bode plots (Fig. 9dee) are also investigated to assess anti-corrosion behaviors. In a Nyquist plot, a big capacitive reactance arc signifies a strong charge transfer impediment, which indicates a better anticorrosion capacity [44]. As shown, the largest capacitive arc for M-M-sample suggests the best corrosion resistance. Fig. 9d shows various amplitude-frequency curves. As seen, low-frequency impedance modulus for M-M-sample is the largest (about 1.2 104U.cm2), followed by M-substrate (about 8.0 103U$cm2) and then substrate (about 0.4 103U$cm2). For phase-frequency
curves (Fig. 9e), Al alloy substrate possesses single time constant (46.5 Hz) relating to interfacial double-layer capacitance between substrate and electrolyte [45]. While for modified surfaces, two time constants at low frequency (26.0 Hz for M-substrate and 12.0 Hz for M-M-sample) and high frequency (822 Hz for M-substrate and 1.23 kHz for M-M-sample) are observed. Note that the highest impedance modulus and lowest time constant at low frequencies indicates the best seawater obstruction for M-M-sample
[46]. The varying tendencies of Bode plots further suggest the best corrosion resistance for M-M-sample.
To accurately determine the electrochemical parameters, ZSimDemo 3.30D Software is used to fit experimental EIS plots. After fittings, the model Rs(Rct1Cdl) in Fig. 10a is suitable for equating electrochemical behaviors of substrate [47]. In this pattern, Rs denotes to solution resistance, Rct1 represents charge transfer resistance, and Cdl is concerned with double layer capacitance. For modified samples, the pattern Rs(Cc(Rc(Cdl(Rct2Ws)))) is found suitable to match their electrochemical behaviors [48], as shown in Fig. 10b. In this pattern, Cc and Rc respectively correspond to capacitance and resistance of modified films. In fact, even for a sealed modified coating, micro-pores inevitably exist thereby promoting ionic penetrations to form corrosive pits, as shown in Fig. 10b. Hence, Ws relating to diffusion resistance is used for depicting impeding capacity of reactant diffusions from solution to substrate [48]. In above models, Cc and Cdl are concerned with constant phase elements (CPE) for illustrating capacitors. The corresponding impedances are expressed as follows [49]:
Zc ¼ Y 1ðjuÞ n (2)
where Y, j, u and n are defined as admittance constant, imaginary number, angular frequency and empirical exponent, respectively.
After fittings, electrochemical parameters of various samples are listed in Table 2. Clearly, small relative standard deviations are
achieved suggesting reasonable fittings. Meanwhile, the increased impedances and decreased capacitances are observed for substrate, M-substrate and M-M-sample successively. This trend also implies gradually improved charge-transfer resistance and anti-corrosion ability for above samples. Furthermore, coating coverage rate a is also used to assess corrosion resistance [50]:
a ¼ 1 Rct1
Rct2
100% (3)
According to Eq. (3), the maximum coating coverage of 97.0% for M-M-sample suggests the best corrosion resistance. The maximum diffusion resistance (Ws) of 9.1 10 4U$cm2 also indicates the optimal corrosion resistance for M-M-sample. Fitting plots are also achieved in Fig. 9, which coincide well with experimental curves. From these, the corrosion resistance is greatly enhanced for M-Msample. It is due to the machined hierarchical structures, which is conducive to trapping air and going against seawater infiltration.
M-M-sample is also prepared with good repellence to acid-base mediums. Fig. 11a exhibits the effect of pH on wetting abilities. As seen, CA and SA remain relatively stable as pH varies suggesting steady liquid repellence in corrosive mediums. Its mechanical stability is evaluated in ultrasound condition (Fig. 11b). After ultrasound for 24 h, M-M-sample maintains super-hydrophobicity. Besides, the stabilities of super-hydrophobic and anti-corrosion behaviors are measured in Fig. 11c and d, respectively. Clearly, after immersion for 30 days, CA, SA, icorr and Ecorr respectively
ettabilities of M-M-sample. (d) Relationship between immersion time in seawater and sults.
maintain at about 160 , 5 , 0.3 mA/cm2 and 0.9 V suggesting excellent durability in seawater. Thus, durable corrosion resistance of M-M-sample arising from its morphology stability (Fig. 11d) is of great potential in broadening possible applications in harsh conditions.

sections.heading: 3.3. Bacteria inhibitions of as-prepared surfaces
sections.text: SRB is used to test bacteria inhibition of M-M-sample. Fig. 12 shows microscopic and fluorescent images of bacterial colonies on comparative samples with diverse culture time. Notably, there is almost no bacteria adhesion on M-M-sample (Fig. 12a) with the minimum bacterial coverage of 0.01% (Fig. 12e) after 2 days. However, more bacteria with a higher coverage of 8.35% (Fig. 12e) are seen on Al alloy substrate (Fig. 12b). After 4 days, a small bacterial coverage of 0.97% (Fig. 12e) is achieved for M-M-sample (Fig. 12c). But for substrate (Fig. 12d), the maximum coverage 24.20% (Fig. 12e) suggests serious microbiological adhesion. The test indicates that the machined super-hydrophobic structures exactly restrain SRB adhesion and growth. As mentioned above, such structures can trap air, which greatly reduces interface interactions with bacterial solution (Fig. 12f). Hence, the simple and low-cost SM process has provided a stable and durable strategy to resist microbiological adhesion.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The subtractive manufacturing of hierarchical micro-craters and nano-terraces has been achieved on AA5052 sheet via EDMprocess. After FAS modification, as-fabricated structures have displayed highlighted water repellence with a static contact angle of 161.3 and a sliding angle of 3.6 . The surface is also prepared with superior anti-adhesion and self-cleaning properties. Meanwhile, the maximal coating coverage of 97.0% is calculated for the resultant surface suggesting the best anti-corrosion capacity by decreasing interactions with corrosive mediums due to newly formed solidair-liquid interfaces. Good chemical stability and durability are
also available for as-prepared surface. Furthermore, the surface is provided with the minimum SRB coverage of 0.01% after 2-day culture suggesting excellent bioadhesion resistance. This work sheds simple and low-cost insights into extending stable and durable applications of Al alloys as barriers against seawater corrosion and bacteria adhesion especially in oceanographic fields.
Credit author statement
B. Li, X. Chen and Z. Guo conceived and designed the experiment. X. Li and T. Shi performed the experiment and wrote the manuscript. C. Zhang revised the manuscript. All authors analyzed the data, checked the article, contributed to the interpretation of the results and revised the manuscript.
